\def \articleTITLE{[Re] One ticket to win them all: generalizing lottery ticket initializations across datasets and optimizers}
\def \articleTYPE{Replication}
\def \articleDOMAIN{NeurIPS 2019 Reproducibility Challenge}
\def \articleBIBLIOGRAPHY{bibliography.bib}
\def \articleYEAR{2020}
\def \reviewURL{https://openreview.net/forum?id=SklFHaqG6S}
\def \articleABSTRACT{    The lottery ticket hypothesis states that smaller subnetworks within a larger deep network can be trained in isolation to achieve accuracy similar to that of original network, as long as they are initialized appropriately. However, whether these subnetworks or winning tickets are transferable across datasets and optimizers remains unclear. The paper "One ticket to win them all:generalizing lottery ticket initializations across datasets and optimizers" empirically shows that these winning tickets are transferable. We reproduce the results in the paper from scratch by implementing all the experiments. Our results support the original paper's claim of the winning ticket initializations being transferable. While the paper is replicable, we find that reproducing the paper requires access to large amount of computing resources for generating the winning tickets. Hence we also open-source the winning tickets we find, so others can avoid the compute-intensive procedure of generating them.}
\def \replicationCITE{A. Morcos, H. Yu, M. Paganini, and Y. Tian. "One ticket to win them all: generalizing lottery ticket initializa-tions across datasets and optimizers." In:Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 32, 2019}
